newsitem.title: USA: BPA says Intertie limits may continue into spring.
newsitem.headline: BPA says Intertie limits may continue into spring.

text.p: The Western Systems Coordinating Council (WSCC) is unlikely to approve a "spring" plan for operating the Pacific Intertie ahead of the expiration of a yet-to-be-finalized "winter" plan, a spokeswoman for the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) said Thursday.

BPA is meeting with a WSCC study group this week to discuss studies for springtime operation of the interstate power transmission system, but will not present a full report until a later date, she noted.
As a result, "it will probably take some time for the study group to pass on a report to the board," the spokeswoman said.
A final decision from the WSCC on BPA's winter operating plan is expected later this month, but it will be in effect only through late April.
The winter plan would raise combined capacity of the lines by about 25 percent to 6,250 megawatts (MW) from a current maximum of 5,200 MW.

If a new spring plan has not cleared all necessary hurdles by the time the winter plan expires - and involved parties say that now appears unlikely - Intertie restrictions will revert back to 5,200 MW in late April.

"With the fish flush coming we are kind of surprised by the length of time this is taking," said the BPA spokeswoman, referring to system operations needed on the Northwest hydroelectric dam system for springtime fish migration.
